net.sf.mmm.search.engine.api

Interface SearchResultPage

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Iterable<SearchHit>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractSearchResultPage, SearchResultPageImpl

    public interface SearchResultPage
extends Iterable<SearchHit>
    This is the interface for a page of a search-result. The total hits are split into pages from 0 to getPageCount() - 1. This instance is the getPageIndex().th page and has getPageHitCount() hits that can be accessed via getPageHit(int). They represent the hits from getPageCount()*getHitsPerPage() to getPageCount()*getHitsPerPage()+getPageHitCount()-1
    You can NOT access hits out of the scope the page represented by this search result. To get hits of a previous or next page, you have to perform a new search.
    Author:
    Joerg Hohwiller (hohwille at users.sourceforge.net)

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static int DEFAULT_HITS_PER_PAGE
      The default number of hits per page.

      This method gets the absolute number of the first hit of this page.

      This method gets the number of pages used to split the total hits.

      This method gets the hit of this page at the given index.

      This method get the number of hits in the page represented by this search result.

      This method gets the index of the page represented by this search result, where 0 is the first page and getPageCount() - 1 is the last page.

      This method gets the page-index of the end page when a number (pagingRange*2)+1 links should be rendered for paging.

      This method gets the original query string that produced this result.
      int getTotalHitCount()
      This method gets the total number of hits for this query.

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_HITS_PER_PAGE

        static final int DEFAULT_HITS_PER_PAGE
        The default number of hits per page.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • getQuery

        String getQuery()
        This method gets the original query string that produced this result.
        Returns:
        the original query string.

      • getTotalHitCount

        int getTotalHitCount()
        This method gets the total number of hits for this query.
        Returns:
        the total number of hits.

      • getHitsPerPage

        int getHitsPerPage()
        This method gets the number of hits per page. The last page may have less hits than this value.
        Returns:
        the number of hits per page.
        See Also:
        DEFAULT_HITS_PER_PAGE

      • getPageCount

        int getPageCount()
        This method gets the number of pages used to split the total hits. An empty search result will have one empty page.
        Returns:
        the number of pages.

      • getPageIndex

        int getPageIndex()
        This method gets the index of the page represented by this search result, where 0 is the first page and getPageCount() - 1 is the last page.
        Returns:
        the index of the page represented by this result.

      • getHitStartNumber

        int getHitStartNumber()
        This method gets the absolute number of the first hit of this page. This is the same as: 
         getPageIndex() * getHitsPerPage() + 1
        Returns:
        the number of the first hit of this page.

      • getHitEndNumber

        int getHitEndNumber()
        This method gets the absolute number of the last hit of this page. This is the same as: 
         getHitStartNumber() + getPageHitCount()
        Returns:
        the number of the last hit of this page.

      • getPageHitCount

        int getPageHitCount()
        This method get the number of hits in the page represented by this search result. The value may be less than the number of hits per page if this is the last page. The value will be greater than zero, except for the first page that may have a page hit count of 0 if the search query produced no hits.
        Returns:
        the number of hits in this page.

      • getPageHit

        SearchHit getPageHit(int index)
        This method gets the hit of this page at the given index.
        Please note, that the index is relative to this page. The absolute index of the hit is getPageIndex()*getHitsPerPage()+index.
        Parameters:
        index - is the index of the requested hit. It has to be in the range from 0 to getPageHitCount() - 1.
        Returns:
        the requested hit.

      • getPagingStartIndex

        int getPagingStartIndex(int pagingRange)
        This method gets the page-index of the start page when a number (pagingRange*2)+1 links should be rendered for paging. The pagingRange actually specifies the number of links forward and backwards.
        The number of result-pages is potentially NOT limited. To avoid that your GUI layout gets broken by too many paging links, you can use this method to render a fixed number of paging links.
        E.g. assume pagingCount is 2 and you would have a page-count of e.g. 10. Then you would render links for visiting the pages from 0 to 4 if your page-index is 0,1 , or 2. For a page-index of 3, you would render the links from 1 to 5 and so on.
        The calculation is performed per call so avoid multiple calls of this method if possible.
        Parameters:
        pagingRange - the number of paging links forward and backwards.
        Returns:
        the page-index to start paging with.
        See Also:
        getPagingEndIndex(int)

      • getPagingEndIndex

        int getPagingEndIndex(int pagingRange)
        This method gets the page-index of the end page when a number (pagingRange*2)+1 links should be rendered for paging. The pagingRange actually specifies the number of links forward and backwards.
        The number of result-pages is potentially NOT limited. To avoid that your GUI layout gets broken by too many paging links, you can use this method to render a fixed number of paging links.
        E.g. assume pagingCount is 2 and you would have a page-count of e.g. 10. Then you would render links for visiting the pages from 5 to 9 if your page-index is 7,8 , or 9. For a page-index of 6, you would render the links from 4 to 8 and so on.
        The calculation is performed per call so avoid multiple calls of this method if possible.
        Parameters:
        pagingRange - the number of paging links forward and backwards.
        Returns:
        the page-index to end paging with.
        See Also:
        getPagingStartIndex(int)
